poem:
Title: In Silent Homage, We Stitch

In the hallowed forest floor,
Sleep relics of an epoch marred by tears,
Shoes, once filled with lives cut short,
Each scrape of leather, a testimony.

We stitch together these orphaned fragments,
Some cleft by time, some flooded with sorrow's rain,
To craft a memory quilt, mournful yet defiant -
A hushed mosaic of millions who never came home.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Every piece of evidence is vital’: Holocaust survivor calls for victims’ shoes to be salvaged One of the last remaining survivors of the Stutthof Nazi concentration camp has appealed to authorities to salvage fragments of tens of thousands of shoes belonging to murdered Holocaust victims that were recently discovered in a forest at the site. Manfred Goldberg, who was imprisoned as a teenager at Stutthof, 24 miles (38km) east of Gdańsk, said he was “shocked". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
